g.text: The limitations of our study include the following:
(1) The number of the included RCTs of risedronate for
preventing bone loss after THA was limited. Most of RCTs
focused on G1 or G2 bisphosphonates for preventing
bone loss after THA. Future studies should be focused on
the comparison between G1/G2 bisphosphonates versus G3
bisphosphonates for THA patients.
(2) The follow-up of the included RCTs ranged from 6 months to
4 years, and more studies should be focused on long-term
ef
ﬁ
cacy of risedronate for bone loss in THA patients.
(3) Type of prosthesis was not unanimous in all of the included
RCTs; more studies should be addressed subgroup analysis
risedronate for different type of prosthesis of THA.
(4) Dose of risedronate was different between the included
studies, so more studies should be given available data about
the optimal dose of risedronate for preventing bone loss after
THA.
5. Conclusions
In conclusion, oral risedronate has an effect on the preservation
of periprosthetic BMD in proximal regions (Gruen zones 1, 2, 3,
and 7) at 3 months after THA. Meanwhile, oral risedronate has a
bene
ﬁ
cial role on the preservation of periprosthetic BMD in all of
the regions at 6 and 12 months after THA. Due to the limited
included studies and shortcoming of this meta-analysis, more
high-quality RCTs were still needed to identify the ef
ﬁ
cacy of
risedronate for bone loss in THA.
Author contributions
Data curation:
Jing Su.
Methodology:
Yi Wei.
Software:
Xiao Ming Li.
Supervision:
Xiao Ming Li, Yan-Ping Diao, Huai-Gang Liu.
Validation:
Yan-Ping Diao, Huai-Gang Liu.
Visualization:
Liang Zhang.
Writing
original draft:
Jing Su, Yi Wei.
Writing
review & editing:
Liang Zhang.
References
[1] Zhao X, Hu D, Qin J, et al. Effect of bisphosphonates in preventing
femoral periprosthetic bone resorption after primary cementless total hip
arthroplasty: a meta-analysis. J Orthop Surg Res 2015;10:65.
[2] Kurtz S, Ong K, Lau E, et al. Projections of primary and revision hip and
knee arthroplasty in the United States from 2005 to 2030. J Bone Joint
[3] Furnes O, Lie SA, Espehaug B, et al. Hip disease and the prognosis of
total hip replacements. A review of 53,698 primary total hip replace-
ments reported to the Norwegian Arthroplasty Register 1987-99. J Bone
Joint Surg Br 2001;83:579
[4] Lin T, Yan SG, Cai XZ, et al. Bisphosphonates for periprosthetic bone
loss after joint arthroplasty: a meta-analysis of 14 randomized controlled
trials. Osteoporos Int 2012;23:1823
[5] Prieto-Alhambra D, Javaid MK, Judge A, et al. Association between
bisphosphonate use and implant survival after primary total arthroplasty
of the knee or hip: population based retrospective cohort study. BMJ
[6] Canales Cortes V, Panisello Sebastiá JJ, Herrera Rodríguez A, et al. Ten-
year follow-up of an anatomical hydroxyapatite-coated total hip
prosthesis. Int Orthop 2006;30:84
[7] Gallo J, Landor I, Cechová I, et al. Comparison of hydroxyapatite-coated
stems in total hip arthroplasty after a minimum 10-years follow-up. Acta
Chir Orthop Traumatol Cech 2008;75:339
[8] Bhandari M, Bajammal S, Guyatt GH, et al. Effect of bisphosphonates on
periprosthetic bone mineral density after total joint arthroplasty. A meta-
analysis. J Bone Joint Surg Am 2005;87:293
[9] Kinov P, Tivchev P, Doukova P, et al. Effect of risedronate on bone
metabolism after total hip arthroplasty: a prospective randomised study.
Acta Orthop Belg 2006;72:44
[10] Sköldenberg OG, Salemyr MO, Bodén HS, et al. The effect of weekly
risedronate on periprosthetic bone resorption following total hip
Figure 6.
Forest plot comparing the serum NTX-I between risedronate group and control group. NTX-I
N-telopeptide of type I collagen.
Su et al. Medicine (2018) 97:51
Medicine
